title: Avant-Garde Beauty Photography: Shutter Drag & Color Grading Deconstruction
summary: Lindsay Adler deconstructs an avant-garde beauty photoshoot featuring pearl makeup. She details a three-light setup using optical spots and bounced fill, demonstrates a creative shutter drag technique involving lens zooming to create starburst effects, and explains her post-processing workflow to achieve a cool, analogous color grade.

steps.action: Introduction to the concept of 'Creative Play Days' and the pearl makeup inspiration.
Set up the Main Light: A strobe with an optical spot, kit lens, and dappled gobo to create irregular, textured light.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, Westcott Optical Spot, Dappled Gobo

steps.action: Set up the Fill Light: A bare strobe bounced into the back corner of the room to lift shadows softly without directionality.
Set up the Background Light: A strobe with a 20-degree grid pointed low at a blue mist background to create a gradient.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, 20 Degree Grid, Savage Universal Blue Mist Background

steps.action: Camera Settings & Gear: Shooting with a Canon R5 and RF 24-105mm lens at 1/20 sec, f/4, ISO 800.
Execute Shutter Drag Technique: Use a slow shutter speed (1/20s) and zoom the lens slightly during exposure to create starburst/blur effects on the pearl highlights.
Color Grading (Raw Processing): Create an analogous color scheme by shifting highlights to Cyan/Green and shadows to Blue.
Retouching: Smooth skin texture, clean up pearl edges, and dodge/burn eyes for emphasis.

key_takeaways: Use 'Creative Play Days' to experiment with new techniques without client constraints.
Optical spots with dappled gobos add complexity and texture to lighting compared to flat softboxes.
Bouncing a bare strobe is an effective way to create soft, non-directional fill light.
Shutter drag combined with a zoom lens can turn static highlights into dynamic starbursts.
Analogous color grading (matching lighting and background tones) creates a cohesive and moody final image.
